title: How to Remove Insect Stains from Fabric

steps.title: Soak the fabric in a basin of cold water for about 30 minutes.
steps.content: Soak the fabric in a basin of cold water for about 30 minutes.

steps.title: Rub the fabric against itself to loosen the insect stain.
steps.content: Rub the fabric against itself to loosen the insect stain.

steps.title: Treat the affected area with an enzyme based cleaner.
steps.content: Treat the affected area with an enzyme based cleaner. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Wash the fabric as you normally would.
steps.content: Wash the fabric as you normally would.

steps.title: Scrape off the excess crusted matter using a brush.
steps.content: Scrape off the excess crusted matter using a brush.

steps.title: Mix 1/2 teaspoon liquid detergent with enzymes, 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) ammonia and 1 US-quart (950 ml) cold water in a basin.
steps.content: Mix 1/2 teaspoon liquid detergent with enzymes, 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) ammonia and 1 US-quart (950 ml) cold water in a basin. Do not use warm water. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Soak the fabric for at least 30 minutes.
steps.content: Soak the fabric for at least 30 minutes. For older insect stains you have to soak it longer.

steps.title: Wash the fabric as you normally would.
steps.content: Wash the fabric as you normally would. If the stain is still visible, repeat the soaking process.

steps.title: Spray cold water on the stained area using a spray bottle.
steps.content: Spray cold water on the stained area using a spray bottle.

steps.title: Blot the area with a cloth.
steps.content: Blot the area with a cloth. Repeat the spraying and blotting process until the insect stain is gone.

steps.title: Dry the area using a towel.
steps.content: Dry the area using a towel.

steps.title: Scrape off the excess dried matter using a brush.
steps.content: Scrape off the excess dried matter using a brush.

steps.title: Mix 1 tablespoon of liquid dish washing detergent with 2 cups of cold water in a large bowl to make a detergent solution.
steps.content: Mix 1 tablespoon of liquid dish washing detergent with 2 cups of cold water in a large bowl to make a detergent solution. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Dip the toothbrush in the solution and gently brush the stained area.
steps.content: Dip the toothbrush in the solution and gently brush the stained area.

steps.title: Blot the area with a clean, wet cloth to rinse the solution.
steps.content: Blot the area with a clean, wet cloth to rinse the solution. Repeat the applying, brushing and rinsing process, if needed.

steps.title: Use a cloth damped with cold water to rinse the remaining solution.
steps.content: Use a cloth damped with cold water to rinse the remaining solution. Rinse thoroughly.

steps.title: Dry the area with a cloth towel.
steps.content: Dry the area with a cloth towel. If stain is still visible, use 3% hydrogen peroxide on the fabric with caution. Pretest on a hidden spot on the material.

steps.title: Moisten the stained area with 3% hydrogen peroxide.
steps.content: Moisten the stained area with 3% hydrogen peroxide. Let it sit for about 5 minutes.

steps.title: Blot the foamy substance with a clean dry cloth.
steps.content: Blot the foamy substance with a clean dry cloth. Repeat the applying and blotting process until the insect stain is gone.

steps.title: Use a cloth damped with cold water to rinse the remaining solution.
steps.content: Use a cloth damped with cold water to rinse the remaining solution. Rinse thoroughly.

steps.title: Use a dry towel to dry the area.
steps.content: Use a dry towel to dry the area.
